No explicit cross-scale causal links are present.

Full Paragraph Text: We are well positioned for growth as we look to cater to the opportunities that emerge as a result of global trends. Our footprint and strong competitive position in emerging markets are strong tailwinds and we are identifying segments that emerge. One such segment is wash additives, a segment which is already approximately 12% of the fabric cleaning market in some parts of the developed world and one we have entered in 2014 in Brazil.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph describes organizational strategy and market positioning but lacks explicit causal relationships between different scales. Global trends are mentioned as creating opportunities, but no specific cross-scale causality is detailed - only correlational positioning and market observations.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Environmental and Societal: Global trends and the fabric cleaning market are societal-level systems.; Organizational: The company ('we') and its entry into wash additives in Brazil.
gpt5: Summary: [Environmental and Societal, Organizational] Global trends create opportunities that the company aims to serve.
gpt5: Rationale: The text explicitly ties global trends to opportunity creation and the firm's intent to act. The 12% market share is noted but not stated as the cause of the Brazil entry, so no additional link.
4o: Rationale: The paragraph discusses market trends and organizational strategies but lacks explicit cross-scale causal interactions between defined scales.
gemini2.5: Links: Environmental and Societal -> Organizational | Organizational -> Environmental and Societal
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Refers to 'We' and 'Our' which represent the company mentioned in the text.; Environmental and Societal: Refers to 'global trends,' 'emerging markets,' 'fabric cleaning market,' and 'Brazil,' which are societal or market-level systems.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Organizational, Environmental and Societal] Global trends create opportunities for the company, which in turn identifies and enters new market segments.
gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph explicitly describes how global trends (Environmental and Societal) create opportunities that the company (Organizational) caters to. Conversely, the company actively identifies and enters new market segments and countries (Environmental and Societal). Only two distinct scales were identified, fitting the protocol.

Full Paragraph Text: Opportunities to upgrade consumers to newer benefits and more convenient formats not only drive growth, but also increase our operating margins by improving the mix of products we sell. A continued focus on delivering our low-cost business model, which unlocks savings across our entire operations, will also contribute to margin expansion, giving us the confidence that we can deliver on our strategic role of increasing the value we generate for Unilever.
claude4: Scale Explanations: Individual: Consumers who upgrade to newer benefits and formats; Organizational: The company (Unilever) implementing business model and operations
claude4: Summary: [Individual, Organizational] Consumer behavior drives company financial performance
claude4: Rationale: The text explicitly states that consumer upgrades to newer products drive organizational growth and operating margins. This represents a clear causal relationship from individual consumer actions to organizational outcomes.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The company ('we', 'our', 'Unilever') executing strategies and managing margins.; Individual: Consumers being 'upgraded to newer benefits and more convenient formats'.
gpt5: Summary: [Organizational, Individual] The firm upgrades consumers to newer benefits/formats, indicating organizational influence on individuals.
gpt5: Rationale: Only the organization and consumers are explicitly referenced. The organization acts on consumers by upgrading them; margin impacts are intra-organizational and not cross-scale. Thus one clear cross-scale link is reported.
4o: Scale Explanations: Individual: Consumers are specific people who are upgraded to newer benefits.; Organizational: Unilever is an organization that benefits from increased margins.
4o: Summary: [Individual, Organizational] Upgrading consumers to newer benefits increases Unilever's operating margins, showing a cross-scale interaction.
4o: Rationale: The paragraph describes how upgrading consumers (Individual) to newer benefits directly impacts Unilever's (Organizational) operating margins. This is a clear cross-scale interaction. No other scales are explicitly involved.
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Individual: Refers to 'consumers' who are upgraded.; Organizational: Refers to 'we' (the company) and 'Unilever' which creates opportunities and benefits from outcomes.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Individual, Organizational] The company upgrades consumers, which in turn drives organizational growth and margin expansion.
gemini2.5: Rationale: The company (Organizational) creates opportunities to upgrade consumers (Individual), establishing the first link. The subsequent upgrading of these consumers (Individual) then causally drives growth and increases operating margins for the company (Organizational), forming the second link. This demonstrates a clear A->B->C hierarchical interaction, broken into two pairwise links, with only two distinct scales identified.

Full Paragraph Text: In laundry, we are rolling out our concentrated liquid brands in eco-packs which drive growth, increase the benefit we deliver to our consumers and improve our profitability, while at the same time reducing our environmental impact.
claude4: Links: Organizational -> Individual | Organizational -> Environmental and Societal
claude4: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The company rolling out concentrated liquid brands; Individual: Consumers receiving benefits from the products; Environmental and Societal: Environmental impact being reduced
claude4: Summary: [Org->Ind->Env] Company's eco-pack rollout benefits consumers while reducing environmental impact
claude4: Rationale: The organizational strategy explicitly drives benefits to individual consumers and environmental improvements. Two clear cross-scale causal relationships are described with the company as the primary actor affecting both consumer benefits and environmental outcomes.
gpt5: Links: Organizational -> Individual | Organizational -> Environmental and Societal
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: "we" rolling out brands in eco-packs refers to a company action.; Individual: "consumers" are customers receiving benefits.; Environmental and Societal: Mentions reducing environmental impact.
gpt5: Summary: [Organizational, Individual, Environmental and Societal] Company eco-pack rollout boosts consumer benefits and reduces environmental impact.
gpt5: Rationale: The text explicitly ties a company's product packaging rollout to outcomes for consumers and the environment. No inter-organizational or sector actors are mentioned, so links are limited to these two cross-scale effects.
4o: Links: Organizational -> Individual | Organizational -> Environmental and Societal
4o: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The company rolling out concentrated liquid brands.; Individual: Consumers benefiting from the products.; Environmental and Societal: The reduced environmental impact.
4o: Summary: [Organizational, Individual, Environmental and Societal] The company enhances consumer benefits and reduces environmental impact with eco-packs.
4o: Rationale: The paragraph describes how the company's actions affect both consumers and the environment. The most critical link is the environmental impact reduction, as it aligns with broader societal goals.
gemini2.5: Links: Organizational -> Individual | Organizational -> Environmental and Societal
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The 'we' refers to a company rolling out products and managing profitability.; Individual: Explicit mention of 'consumers' as recipients of benefit.; Environmental and Societal: Explicit mention of 'environmental impact' as an outcome.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Organizational, Individual, Environmental and Societal] A company's product strategy causally impacts consumers and the environment.
gemini2.5: Rationale: The company (Organizational) explicitly states its eco-pack strategy causally benefits consumers (Individual) and reduces environmental impact (Environmental and Societal). Two distinct cross-scale links are identified, both stemming from the Organizational scale. The three detected scales are within the allowed limit.

Full Paragraph Text: Eco-packs use less plastic, meaning up to 70% less plastic used and a 50-85% reduction in greenhouse gases per consumer use. Simultaneously, a reduction in plastic packaging delivers a significant cost saving, allowing us to pass on lower costs to our consumers and improve the category profitability. Overall, eco-packs have a significantly lower impact on the environment compared to traditional packaging.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph describes eco-pack benefits (reduced plastic, lower costs, environmental impact) but lacks explicit actors at different scales causing effects on each other. No clear hierarchical causality is established between distinct scale levels.
gpt5: Links: Organizational -> Individual | Organizational -> Environmental and Societal
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: "us" implies a company implementing eco-packs and pricing decisions; Individual: "consumers" are the recipients of lower costs; Environmental and Societal: "environment" and "greenhouse gases" are societal/environmental systems
gpt5: Summary: [Organizational, Individual, Environmental and Societal] The firm’s eco-packs cut GHGs and environmental impact and let it pass lower costs to consumers.
gpt5: Rationale: The company’s adoption of eco-packs causally reduces GHGs/environmental impact and enables passing lower prices to consumers, both explicit. I excluded "category profitability" (sector-level) due to ambiguity and to stay within three scales.
4o: Links: Organizational -> Individual | Organizational -> Environmental and Societal
4o: Scale Explanations: Individual: Consumers are affected by cost savings.; Organizational: Organizations implement eco-packs and experience cost savings.; Environmental and Societal: Eco-packs reduce greenhouse gases and plastic use.
4o: Summary: [Individual, Organizational, Environmental and Societal] Organizations use eco-packs to reduce costs and environmental impact, benefiting consumers and the environment.
4o: Rationale: The paragraph describes how organizations' use of eco-packs leads to cost savings for consumers and environmental benefits. These are clear cross-scale interactions involving three scales.
gemini2.5: Links: Organizational -> Environmental and Societal | Individual -> Environmental and Societal | Organizational -> Individual
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Individual: Refers to 'consumers' who use eco-packs and receive lower costs.; Organizational: Refers to 'us' (the company/brand) that produces eco-packs and passes on savings.; Environmental and Societal: Refers to 'greenhouse gases' and the 'environment' impacted by packaging.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Individual, Organizational, Environmental and Societal] Organizational decisions on eco-packs influence both environmental impact and individual consumer costs, while individual consumer use also affects the environment.
gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph explicitly describes how an Organizational actor's product (eco-packs) causally influences both the Environmental and Societal scale (reduced GHG) and the Individual scale (lower costs for consumers). Additionally, Individual consumer actions (use) are stated to impact the Environmental and Societal scale. Three distinct scales were identified and linked causally.

Full Paragraph Text: Having launched eco-packs in the UK, Italy and Switzerland, we are aiming to launch them across Europe in 2015.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph describes a company's product launch timeline and geographic expansion plans but contains no explicit causal interactions between different hierarchical scales. It only states past actions and future intentions without describing cross-scale influences.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: "we" refers to one company acting (launching products).; Environmental and Societal: Countries/region (UK, Italy, Switzerland, Europe) are societal markets/communities.
gpt5: Summary: [Organizational, Environmental and Societal] The company’s product launches target national and Europe-wide markets.
gpt5: Rationale: The organization acts to introduce products into societal-level markets (countries/Europe), an explicit cross-scale action. No other scales are mentioned, so only these two are used.
4o: Rationale: The paragraph describes an organizational action (launching eco-packs) but does not explicitly mention any cross-scale causal influence involving other scales such as individuals or societal systems.
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: N/A
gemini2.5: Summary: N/A
gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph describes an organizational actor's plan to launch products in various geographical regions. It does not explicitly state any causal influence between the organizational actor and actors or systems at other scales (Individual, Inter-Organizational, or Environmental and Societal). The regions mentioned are targets for market expansion, not described as causally interacting entities.

Full Paragraph Text: In September 2015 the UN will agree a new set of Sustainable Development Goals. In December Paris hosts the next major UN Climate Change Summit. The close link between human development and climate will focus the world on growth that is more inclusive, sustained and sustainable.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph describes future events and correlations between development and climate issues but lacks explicit causal relationships between actors at different scales. The UN's actions are mentioned as future agreements rather than current influences on other scale actors.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The UN is a single organization running the summit and setting SDGs.; Environmental and Societal: Paris (city/government) is a governmental host, a societal-level actor.
gpt5: Summary: [Environmental and Societal, Organizational] Paris (city/government) hosts the UN climate summit, enabling the UN event.
gpt5: Rationale: The text explicitly states Paris hosts the UN summit, a societal actor enabling an organizational activity. Other statements (UN agreeing SDGs; world focus) lack explicit cross-scale causality between defined actors.
4o: Rationale: The paragraph describes events and themes but lacks explicit cross-scale causal interactions. No specific actions or influences between defined scales are mentioned.
gemini2.5: Links: Organizational -> Environmental and Societal | Environmental and Societal -> Organizational
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The 'UN' is a single organization.; Environmental and Societal: 'Sustainable Development Goals' are societal frameworks; 'Paris' is a city/societal context; 'human development,' 'climate,' 'world,' and 'growth' are societal/environmental systems.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Organizational, Environmental and Societal] The UN agrees societal goals, and Paris hosts the UN Climate Change Summit.
gemini2.5: Rationale: The UN (Organizational) explicitly agrees to societal-level Sustainable Development Goals (Environmental and Societal). Conversely, Paris (Environmental and Societal) explicitly hosts the UN Climate Change Summit (Organizational), enabling the organizational event. Only two distinct scales were identified, adhering to the protocol.

Full Paragraph Text: With this in mind, in 2014 Unilever examined where it can bring about improvements on a larger, societal scale by creating transformational change in key areas relevant to our business. These are: • the elimination of deforestation; • championing sustainable agriculture and the development of smallholder farmers; and • improving health and hygiene through handwashing, safe drinking water and sanitation.
claude4: Links: Organizational -> Environmental and Societal | Organizational -> Individual
claude4: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever as a specific company examining and creating change; Environmental and Societal: Larger societal scale, deforestation, sustainable agriculture systems; Individual: Smallholder farmers as specific people being developed
claude4: Summary: [Organizational, Environmental and Societal, Individual] Unilever creates societal transformational change and develops smallholder farmers
claude4: Rationale: Unilever as an organization explicitly acts to create change at both societal level (deforestation, agriculture systems) and individual level (farmer development). The text clearly states causal action from the company to these other scales.
gpt5: Links: Organizational -> Environmental and Societal | Organizational -> Individual
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever is a single company taking action.; Environmental and Societal: Targets: larger societal improvements, eliminating deforestation, health/hygiene.; Individual: Smallholder farmers are individuals whose development is targeted.
gpt5: Summary: [Organizational, Environmental and Societal, Individual] Unilever aims to drive societal change (deforestation, health) and develop smallholder farmers.
gpt5: Rationale: The text explicitly states Unilever intends to cause societal-level improvements and to develop smallholder farmers, creating cross-scale links. No inter-organizational system is specified, so only these three scales are used.
4o: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever is a specific company.; Environmental and Societal: The societal scale includes deforestation, agriculture, and public health.
4o: Summary: [Organizational, Environmental and Societal] Unilever seeks to impact societal issues like deforestation and health.
4o: Rationale: Unilever (Organizational) is explicitly acting to influence societal issues (Environmental and Societal) such as deforestation and public health. No other scales are present.
gemini2.5: Links: Organizational -> Environmental and Societal | Organizational -> Individual
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever is a single company.; Environmental and Societal: Explicitly mentioned 'societal scale,' 'deforestation,' 'sustainable agriculture,' 'health and hygiene,' 'handwashing,' 'safe drinking water,' and 'sanitation' are societal/environmental issues.; Individual: 'Smallholder farmers' are specific people.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Organizational, Environmental and Societal, Individual] Unilever aims to improve societal and environmental conditions and develop smallholder farmers.
gemini2.5: Rationale: Unilever (Organizational) explicitly aims to influence the societal scale (Environmental and Societal) through improvements and championing sustainable agriculture. It also targets the development of smallholder farmers (Individual). All three scales are clearly identified and causally linked.

Full Paragraph Text: Later in this section we have highlighted new, related areas of Unilever activity under way in 2014 that are of broad benefit to society, including our work on behalf of women, which will continue to develop in the next few years.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph only describes Unilever's activities and future plans without establishing any explicit causal relationships between different scales. While Unilever (Organizational) and society/women (Environmental and Societal) are mentioned, no cross-scale influence or causality is explicitly stated.
gpt5: Links: Organizational -> Environmental and Societal | Organizational -> Individual
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever is a single company.; Environmental and Societal: "society" is a societal-level actor.; Individual: "women" denotes people as a demographic group.
gpt5: Summary: [Organizational, Environmental and Societal, Individual] Unilever’s activities benefit society and include work directed at women.
gpt5: Rationale: The text explicitly states Unilever’s activities benefit society, establishing org-to-societal causality. It also notes work on behalf of women, implying org-to-individual influence. Only these three scales appear.
4o: Rationale: The paragraph mentions Unilever's activities benefiting society but lacks explicit cross-scale causal interactions.
gemini2.5: Links: Organizational -> Environmental and Societal | Organizational -> Individual
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever is a single company.; Individual: Refers to specific people ('women').; Environmental and Societal: Refers to 'society' as a broad system.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Organizational, Individual, Environmental and Societal] Unilever's activities and work benefit society and women, demonstrating organizational influence across individual and societal scales.
gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph explicitly describes Unilever (Organizational) undertaking activities that benefit society (Environmental and Societal) and working on behalf of women (Individual). These are clear causal influences from one scale to another. Three distinct scales were identified, adhering to the protocol.

Full Paragraph Text: Sustainability is an integral part of our business model. It meets growing consumer preference for responsible consumption and retailers’ own sustainability targets. It acts as a catalyst for innovation, thus developing new markets, and is an inspiration to Unilever’s current and future employees.
claude4: Links: Individual -> Organizational | Inter-Organizational / Sector -> Organizational | Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector
claude4: Scale Explanations: Individual: consumers with preferences, current and future employees; Organizational: Unilever as a specific company with business model and employees; Inter-Organizational / Sector: retailers as a sector with sustainability targets, new markets being developed
claude4: Summary: [Individual, Organizational, Inter-Organizational] Consumer preferences and retailer targets shape Unilever's sustainability-driven business model
claude4: Rationale: The text explicitly describes how consumer preferences and retailer sustainability targets influence Unilever's business model, while Unilever's sustainability efforts catalyze market development. Multiple clear cross-scale causal relationships are present.
gpt5: Links: Organizational -> Individual | Organizational -> Environmental and Societal
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever’s business model integrating sustainability; Individual: Consumers and Unilever’s employees are specific people/groups; Environmental and Societal: “New markets” refers to market systems at a societal level
gpt5: Summary: [Organizational, Individual, Environmental and Societal] Company sustainability inspires employees and helps develop new markets.
gpt5: Rationale: Explicit org-to-individual influence appears via employee inspiration; consumer preference mention is alignment, not causal on the org. Retailers are organizations, so org-to-org links were excluded.
4o: Links: Environmental and Societal -> Organizational | Individual -> Organizational
4o: Scale Explanations: Individual: Consumers and employees are specific people.; Organizational: Unilever is a specific company.; Environmental and Societal: Retailers' sustainability targets reflect societal norms.
4o: Summary: [Individual, Organizational, Environmental and Societal] Consumer preferences and societal norms influence Unilever's sustainability strategy.
4o: Rationale: The paragraph describes how consumer preferences and societal norms (retailers' targets) influence Unilever's business model. These are clear cross-scale interactions.
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Individual: Refers to 'consumer preference' and 'Unilever’s current and future employees'.; Organizational: Refers to 'our business model' (Unilever) and 'retailers'.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Individual, Organizational] Consumer preferences influence Unilever's business model, which in turn inspires its employees.
gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph explicitly links consumer preferences (Individual) to Unilever's business model (Organizational) and then Unilever's business model (Organizational) to its employees (Individual). The interaction with 'retailers' is between two Organizational actors and thus not cross-scale. Abstract concepts like 'innovation' and 'new markets' are not concrete actors.

Full Paragraph Text: Alleviating social problems, such as the lack of effective sanitation, safe drinking water and related hygiene issues, helps communities while increasing sales of brands like Domestos, Pureit and Lifebuoy.
claude4: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Specific brands (Domestos, Pureit, Lifebuoy) as commercial entities; Environmental and Societal: Communities facing social problems like sanitation and water access
claude4: Summary: [Organizational, Environmental and Societal] Brand sales activities help alleviate community social problems while increasing revenue
claude4: Rationale: The text explicitly states that brand activities help communities with social problems while increasing sales, showing clear organizational-to-societal causality. Only two distinct scales are present.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Environmental and Societal: Social conditions and communities (sanitation, water, hygiene) are societal-level.; Organizational: Brands like Domestos, Pureit, and Lifebuoy are organizational actors with sales outcomes.
gpt5: Summary: [Environmental and Societal, Organizational] Alleviating sanitation, water, and hygiene problems increases sales of brands like Domestos, Pureit, and Lifebuoy.
gpt5: Rationale: The sentence explicitly links societal problem alleviation to increased brand sales, a cross-scale causal effect. The 'helps communities' part is same-scale and excluded. Only these two scales are needed.
4o: Scale Explanations: Environmental and Societal: Communities are affected by social problems like sanitation and water issues.; Organizational: Brands like Domestos, Pureit, and Lifebuoy are organizations that benefit from increased sales.
4o: Summary: [Environmental and Societal, Organizational] Improving community sanitation boosts sales for brands like Domestos.
4o: Rationale: The paragraph describes how addressing societal issues like sanitation directly benefits organizations by increasing their sales. This establishes a clear cross-scale interaction between societal improvements and organizational gains.
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: N/A
gemini2.5: Summary: N/A
gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph describes a causal relationship where 'alleviating social problems' leads to effects on 'communities' (Environmental and Societal) and 'brands' (Organizational). However, 'alleviating social problems' is an action/condition, not an explicit actor at a defined scale, which is a strict requirement for identifying a hierarchical interaction.

Full Paragraph Text: Access to sustainable and plentiful raw materials reduces volatility and mitigates risk. More efficient use of energy and the development of packaging with less plastic further reduces costs. Brand reputation is defended and enhanced.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph describes general business benefits and outcomes (reduced volatility, cost reduction, enhanced brand reputation) without identifying specific actors or explicit causal relationships between different organizational scales. No concrete entities are mentioned that could be mapped to distinct scales.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: N/A
gpt5: Summary: N/A
gpt5: Rationale: No concrete cross-scale actors are named. The statements describe generic organizational outcomes (cost, risk, reputation) without explicit causal links to a different scale.
4o: Rationale: The paragraph discusses benefits of sustainable practices but lacks explicit cross-scale causal interactions. No specific actors at different scales are identified or linked causally.
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: N/A
gemini2.5: Summary: N/A
gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph describes general benefits (reduced volatility, costs, enhanced brand reputation) for an implied organizational actor. However, it lacks explicit actors or causal relationships between different defined scales, focusing instead on internal organizational outcomes.

Full Paragraph Text: Unilever is one of the world’s biggest buyers of palm oil as a raw material for use in a number of our Foods and Personal Care brands. Palm oil is recognised as one of the four major commodities driving deforestation, which contributes up to 15% of the world’s greenhouse gas emissions.
claude4: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever as a specific company purchasing palm oil; Environmental and Societal: Global deforestation and greenhouse gas emissions systems
claude4: Summary: [Organizational, Environmental] Unilever's palm oil use contributes to global deforestation and emissions
claude4: Rationale: Clear causal chain from Unilever's purchasing behavior to environmental impacts. Palm oil is explicitly identified as driving deforestation, which contributes to emissions. Only two distinct scales present.
gpt5: Scales: Organizational, Inter-Organizational / Sector, Environmental and Societal
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever is a single company.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The palm oil commodity denotes a sector spanning many organizations.; Environmental and Societal: Deforestation and world greenhouse gas emissions are societal-environmental systems.
gpt5: Summary: [Organizational | Inter-Organizational / Sector | Environmental and Societal] The palm oil commodity sector is said to drive deforestation.
gpt5: Rationale: The paragraph explicitly links a sector-level commodity to deforestation, yielding a cross-scale link. Unilever’s purchasing is not explicitly tied causally to deforestation. Deforestation to GHG is same-scale, so excluded.
4o: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever is a specific company.; Environmental and Societal: Deforestation and greenhouse gas emissions are societal-level issues.
4o: Summary: [Organizational, Environmental and Societal] Unilever's palm oil use contributes to deforestation, affecting global emissions.
4o: Rationale: Unilever's actions as an organization directly influence environmental issues like deforestation and emissions. No other scales are explicitly involved.
gemini2.5: Scales: Organizational, Inter-Organizational / Sector, Environmental and Societal
gemini2.5: Links: Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector | Inter-Organizational / Sector -> Environmental and Societal
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever is a single company.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The global palm oil commodity market/supply chain represents a system of collaborations among organizations.; Environmental and Societal: Deforestation and greenhouse gas emissions represent impacts on ecosystems and the global climate system, which are societal-level systems.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Organizational, Inter-Organizational / Sector, Environmental and Societal] Unilever's palm oil purchasing influences the commodity market, which drives deforestation and impacts environmental systems.
gemini2.5: Rationale: The text describes Unilever (Organizational) as a major buyer influencing the palm oil commodity market (Inter-Organizational / Sector). This market, in turn, drives deforestation, impacting ecosystems (Environmental and Societal). The subsequent link from deforestation to greenhouse gas emissions occurs within the Environmental and Societal scale, thus not forming a cross-scale interaction.

Full Paragraph Text: We have committed to source 100% of our palm oil sustainably from certified, traceable sources by 2020. We also set ourselves the ambition that, by the end of 2014, all the palm oil we buy would be traceable to known sources. On that ambition we still have work to do but we have achieved a significant milestone in our European Foods business.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph describes organizational commitments and achievements regarding palm oil sourcing but contains no explicit causal interactions between different scales. It only reports internal organizational goals and progress without describing how these actions influence or are influenced by other scale levels.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The company ('We') and its European Foods business are organizational actors.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: Certified, traceable palm oil sources/supply chain from which the company purchases.
gpt5: Summary: [Organizational, Inter-Organizational/Sector] The company’s sourcing policy mandates purchasing only from certified, traceable supply-chain sources.
gpt5: Rationale: The text explicitly shows an organizational commitment constraining the inter-organizational supply chain. No societal or individual actors are specified. The European Foods unit is same-scale, so only one cross-scale link is valid.
4o: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The company itself is setting goals and tracking progress.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The sourcing of palm oil involves certified, traceable sources, indicating a supply chain.
4o: Summary: [Organizational, Inter-Organizational / Sector] The company influences the supply chain by committing to sustainable palm oil sourcing.
4o: Rationale: The company (Organizational) sets a goal to source palm oil sustainably, impacting the supply chain (Inter-Organizational / Sector). No other scales are explicitly involved.
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Refers to 'We' (the company) and 'European Foods business'.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: Refers to 'certified, traceable sources' and 'known sources' as elements of the supply chain system.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Organizational, Inter-Organizational / Sector] The company commits to influence its supply chain by demanding certified and traceable palm oil sources.
gemini2.5: Rationale: The company (Organizational) explicitly commits to source palm oil from 'certified, traceable sources' and sets an ambition for 'known sources'. These requirements causally influence the standards and practices within its supply chain (Inter-Organizational / Sector).

Full Paragraph Text: In June 2014 Unilever, along with fellow members of the Consumer Goods Forum, called on heads of state for a binding global climate change deal. In September 2014 we helped facilitate the New York Declaration on Forests at the UN Climate Summit where more than 170 governments, companies and NGOs pledged to cut forest loss by half by 2020, end it by 2030 and restore 350 million hectares of degraded land.
claude4: Scales: Organizational, Inter-Organizational / Sector, Environmental and Societal
claude4: Links: Inter-Organizational / Sector -> Environmental and Societal | Organizational -> Environmental and Societal
claude4: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever as a single company; Inter-Organizational / Sector: Consumer Goods Forum as industry alliance; Environmental and Societal: Heads of state, governments, UN Climate Summit as societal-level systems
claude4: Summary: [Inter-Org, Org, Env&Soc] Industry alliance and company influence government climate policy
claude4: Rationale: Two clear cross-scale interactions: industry forum calling on governments and company facilitating UN declaration. Both represent organizational actors influencing societal-level policy systems.
gpt5: Scales: Organizational, Inter-Organizational / Sector, Environmental and Societal
gpt5: Links: Inter-Organizational / Sector -> Environmental and Societal | Organizational -> Environmental and Societal
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever; companies and NGOs are individual organizations.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: Consumer Goods Forum is a coalition of companies acting collectively.; Environmental and Societal: Heads of state and governments are societal-level government actors.

Full Paragraph Text: Also in the same month, Unilever and the World Resources Institute announced a partnership aimed at increasing transparency in agricultural commodity supply chains. This will enable Unilever and our suppliers to use the Global Forest Watch Commodities platform to monitor forest cover change around commodity supply areas and processing facilities such as palm oil mills.
claude4: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever (company) and World Resources Institute (NGO) as individual organizations; Inter-Organizational / Sector: Agricultural commodity supply chains involving multiple suppliers and processing facilities
claude4: Summary: [Organizational, Inter-Organizational] Partnership enables supply chain transparency and monitoring across supplier networks
claude4: Rationale: The partnership between two organizations (Unilever and WRI) explicitly aims to influence and monitor inter-organizational supply chain systems. The text clearly states this will enable monitoring across supplier networks and processing facilities.

gpt5: Summary: [Organizational, Inter-Organizational / Sector] Orgs form a partnership that then enables Unilever and suppliers to use a platform.
gpt5: Rationale: The text explicitly states that two organizations create a partnership and that this partnership enables organizational actions. Environmental monitoring is mentioned but not as a causal effect on or by the environment, so it was excluded.
4o: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever and its suppliers are specific organizations.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The partnership and supply chains involve multiple organizations.
4o: Summary: [Organizational, Inter-Organizational / Sector] The partnership allows Unilever and suppliers to monitor forest changes using a shared platform.
4o: Rationale: The paragraph describes a partnership (Inter-Org) enabling Unilever and suppliers (Org) to use a platform. No Environmental and Societal scale is directly influenced.

This action then enables Organizational actors (Unilever, suppliers) to monitor Environmental and Societal outcomes (forest cover change).

Full Paragraph Text: Unilever’s work in moving from commitment to action in combating deforestation has been recognised. In November, we were ranked joint first for corporate action on tackling deforestation in our sector by CDP, formerly the Carbon Disclosure Project. The CDP report was produced on behalf of 240 investors, who together represent US $15 trillion in assets, and analysed the disclosures of 152 companies from around the world. It said: “Companies that regularly respond to CDP’s forests program are now identifying many more opportunities available to them, including securing their supply chain against the risks associated with deforestation and commodity sourcing. This in turn is helping to secure shareholder value.”
claude4: Scales: Organizational, Inter-Organizational / Sector, Environmental and Societal
claude4: Links: Inter-Organizational / Sector -> Organizational | Environmental and Societal -> Inter-Organizational / Sector | Inter-Organizational / Sector -> Environmental and Societal
claude4: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever as a specific company and the 152 analyzed companies; Inter-Organizational / Sector: CDP program, supply chains, and sector-wide corporate actions; Environmental and Societal: 240 investors representing $15 trillion in assets and shareholder value systems
claude4: Summary: [Organizational, Inter-Organizational, Environmental] CDP program ranks companies while serving investor interests and securing shareholder value
claude4: Rationale: The text shows explicit causality: investors commission CDP analysis, CDP evaluates companies, and this process secures shareholder value. Each link represents direct influence described in the paragraph.
gpt5: Scales: Organizational, Inter-Organizational / Sector, Environmental and Societal

gpt5: Summary: [Organizational, Inter-Organizational / Sector, Environmental and Societal] Investors prompted CDP’s report; companies secured supply chains, which in turn helped secure shareholder value.
gpt5: Rationale: Investors (capital markets) caused CDP (an organization) to produce the report. Companies’ actions affected supply chains, and secured supply chains helped shareholder value. Same-scale org–org effects were excluded.
4o: Scales: Organizational, Inter-Organizational / Sector, Environmental and Societal
4o: Links: Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector | Inter-Organizational / Sector -> Environmental and Societal
4o: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever is a specific company.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: CDP report involves multiple companies and investors.; Environmental and Societal: Investors represent a societal-level financial system.
4o: Summary: [Organizational, Inter-Organizational / Sector, Environmental and Societal] Unilever's deforestation actions influenced its CDP ranking, affecting investor decisions and societal assets.
4o: Rationale: Unilever's actions (Organizational) led to a high CDP ranking (Inter-Organizational / Sector), which impacts investor decisions (Environmental and Societal). These scales are clearly defined and linked.

Unilever is a single company.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: Refers to a collective of 152 companies or 'companies' generally within a sector, indicating sector-level dynamics and supply chain actions.; Environmental and Societal: 240 investors represent capital markets. Shareholder value is an outcome within the capital market system.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Organizational, Inter-Organizational / Sector, Environmental and Societal] Investors influence CDP, whose program guides companies in securing supply chains, ultimately impacting shareholder value.
gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph describes a causal chain where Environmental and Societal actors (investors) influence an Organizational actor (CDP). CDP's program then guides Inter-Organizational / Sector actors (companies) to take actions that, in turn, secure Environmental and Societal outcomes (shareholder value). Three distinct scales were clearly identified and linked.

Full Paragraph Text: In 2014 we were able to announce a significant achievement that by the end of the year all palm oil directly sourced for Unilever’s European Foods business was close to 100% traceable and certified sustainable (over 98% in December 2014 and on track to be 100% by the end of March 2015).
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph describes Unilever's achievement in sourcing sustainable palm oil but contains no explicit cross-scale causal interactions. It only reports an organizational outcome without describing how different scales influenced each other.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: N/A
gpt5: Summary: N/A
gpt5: Rationale: The text reports Unilever’s achievement/status on palm oil traceability and certification but does not state a causal influence between distinct scales.
4o: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever's European Foods business is a specific organization.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The sourcing of palm oil involves supply chains and certification systems.
4o: Summary: [Organizational, Inter-Organizational / Sector] The traceability and certification of palm oil supply chains impact Unilever's European Foods business operations.
4o: Rationale: The paragraph describes how the certification and traceability of palm oil, a supply chain activity, directly affect Unilever's business operations. This is a clear cross-scale interaction between the supply chain and the organization.
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: N/A
gemini2.5: Summary: N/A
gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph describes an achievement by Unilever's European Foods business (Organizational scale) regarding the attributes of its sourced palm oil. It does not explicitly state any causal influence from or to another distinct scale. The 'certified sustainable' status is an attribute of the product, not an explicit interaction between different scales or actors.

Full Paragraph Text: On a global level Unilever is working hard to drive transparency in the palm oil supply chain. We now have visibility of about 1,800 crude palm oil mills, representing around two thirds of all mills in the global palm oil industry. We can also demonstrate traceability to a consumer product, which five years ago appeared unachievable. This represents a considerable breakthrough for Unilever and the food industry generally.
claude4: Links: Organizational -> Inter-Organizational / Sector | Inter-Organizational / Sector -> Individual
claude4: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever as a single company driving transparency initiatives; Inter-Organizational / Sector: Palm oil supply chain involving multiple organizations and mills across the industry; Individual: Consumers who purchase and use the traceable products
claude4: Summary: [Org->Inter-Org->Individual] Unilever drives palm oil supply chain transparency, enabling product traceability to consumers
claude4: Rationale: Two clear cross-scale links: Unilever (organizational) actively transforming supply chain systems (inter-organizational), which then enables traceability to consumer products (individual level). The chain flows from company action to industry transformation to consumer benefit.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever is a single company.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The palm oil supply chain and the global food industry are sector-level systems.
gpt5: Summary: [Organizational, Inter-Organizational / Sector] Unilever acts to increase transparency in the palm oil supply chain, benefiting the broader food industry.
gpt5: Rationale: The text explicitly states Unilever is driving transparency in a sector-level supply chain. Other mentions (mills, consumer product) do not state cross-scale causality. Thus only Org -> Inter-Org is included.
4o: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever is a specific organization.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The palm oil supply chain involves multiple organizations.
4o: Summary: [Organizational, Inter-Organizational / Sector] Unilever's actions enhance transparency in the palm oil supply chain, impacting the food industry.
4o: Rationale: Unilever (Organizational) is actively improving transparency in the palm oil supply chain (Inter-Organizational / Sector), showing a clear cross-scale interaction. No other scales are explicitly involved.

gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever and crude palm oil mills are specific organizations.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: Palm oil supply chain, global palm oil industry, and food industry represent systems or collaborations among organizations.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Organizational, Inter-Organizational / Sector] Unilever's organizational efforts drive transparency and breakthroughs within the broader inter-organizational palm oil and food industries.
gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph explicitly describes Unilever (Organizational) influencing the palm oil supply chain and food industry (both Inter-Organizational / Sector) through its efforts in transparency and achieving breakthroughs. Only two distinct scales were identified, meeting the scale limitation.

Full Paragraph Text: Unilever is determined to work with the palm oil industry to drive deforestation out of its supply chain. Knowing the origin of palm oil is vital to halt deforestation.

claude4: Summary: [Org->Inter-Org->Env] Unilever works with palm oil industry to eliminate deforestation from supply chains
claude4: Rationale: Clear causal chain where Unilever influences industry practices, which in turn affects environmental outcomes. Two explicit cross-scale interactions form a sequential pathway from company to environmental impact.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever is a single company.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The palm oil industry and a supply chain are multi-organization systems.
gpt5: Summary: [Organizational, Inter-Organizational] Unilever plans to work with the palm oil industry to change its supply chain.
gpt5: Rationale: The text explicitly states Unilever will act with the industry to alter its supply chain, a cross-scale link from organization to inter-org. Deforestation is a phenomenon, not an actor, so environmental scale is excluded.

4o: Rationale: Unilever (Organizational) is explicitly working with the palm oil industry (Inter-Organizational) to address deforestation, showing a clear cross-scale interaction.

gemini2.5: Rationale: The text explicitly describes Unilever (Organizational) engaging with the palm oil industry (Inter-Organizational / Sector). This collaboration then aims to causally influence deforestation (Environmental and Societal) by driving it out of the supply chain.

Full Paragraph Text: We want to build on our progress in Europe by repeating the achievement internationally. One of the next steps is our new processing plant in Sei Mangke, Indonesia. The plant is a significant investment to source palm oil from known and certified sources for our global use.
claude4: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The company making the investment and operating the processing plant; Environmental and Societal: Indonesia as a country/region where the plant is located

gpt5: Rationale: The text explicitly links the company’s plant investment to sourcing from certified suppliers, a supply-chain action. No other scale interactions are stated, so only org-to-inter-org is included.
4o: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The company building the processing plant.; Environmental and Societal: The sourcing of palm oil from certified sources.

gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Refers to 'We' (the company) and 'our new processing plant'.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: Refers to 'known and certified sources', implying a network of suppliers or a supply chain.; Environmental and Societal: Refers to 'Europe', 'internationally', and 'Sei Mangke, Indonesia' as geographical and market contexts.

The new plant (Organizational) causally interacts with Inter-Organizational / Sector supply chains by sourcing from them. Only three distinct scales were identified, adhering to the protocol.

Full Paragraph Text: In 2014 Unilever enhanced its Unilever Sustainable Living Plan (USLP) by introducing new pillars to its goal of enhancing livelihoods. These were: fairness in the workplace, where we will advance human rights across our operations and extended supply chain; opportunities for women, where we will empower 5 million women by 2020; and inclusive business, where we will have a positive impact on the lives of 5.5 million people by 2020.
claude4: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever as a single company implementing USLP; Inter-Organizational / Sector: Extended supply chain involving multiple organizations; Individual: 5 million women and 5.5 million people as specific individuals
claude4: Summary: [Organizational, Inter-Organizational, Individual] Unilever's USLP targets supply chain human rights and individual empowerment
claude4: Rationale: Unilever explicitly commits to advancing human rights across its supply chain and directly impacting millions of individuals through empowerment programs. The supply chain link represents organizational influence on inter-organizational systems, while the individual impact represents direct organizational-to-individual influence.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever as a single company implementing the USLP.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The 'extended supply chain' spanning multiple organizations.; Individual: Women and people whose lives are targeted for empowerment/impact.
gpt5: Summary: [Organizational, Inter-Organizational / Sector, Individual] Unilever’s plan pushes human rights across its supply chain and commits to empower 5M women, directly affecting individuals.
gpt5: Rationale: The text explicitly states Unilever’s actions affecting its multi-organization supply chain and individual women/people. No explicit societal/government actor is named, so scales are limited to these three.
4o: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever is a company implementing the USLP.; Individual: The plan aims to empower and impact millions of individuals.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The plan involves Unilever's extended supply chain.
4o: Summary: [Organizational, Individual, Inter-Organizational / Sector] Unilever's USLP aims to empower individuals and influence its supply chain, showing cross-scale interactions.
4o: Rationale: The paragraph describes Unilever's organizational actions affecting individuals and its supply chain. These interactions are explicit, with clear goals and targets.
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever is a single company.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The extended supply chain represents a system among organizations.; Individual: Women and people are specific groups of individuals.

gemini2.5: Rationale: The text explicitly describes Unilever (Organizational) acting to influence its extended supply chain (Inter-Organizational / Sector) and directly impacting women and people (Individual). All identified scales are distinct and causal relationships are clearly stated. Only three distinct scales were identified, adhering to the protocol.

Full Paragraph Text: This latter commitment includes improving livelihoods of smallholder farmers and links directly to our USLP goal of reducing our environmental impact through sustainable sourcing.

While smallholder farmers (Individual) and USLP goals (Organizational) are mentioned, no direct causal influence is stated - only that commitments 'include' and 'link to' these elements without specifying how one scale affects another.

gpt5: Summary: [Organizational, Individual, Environmental and Societal] The organization commits to improve smallholder farmers’ livelihoods and to reduce environmental impact via sustainable sourcing.
gpt5: Rationale: The text explicitly ties an organizational commitment to improving individuals’ livelihoods and to reducing environmental impact. No inter-organizational actor is named, so sector-level links are excluded.

Full Paragraph Text: Around half of Unilever’s raw materials come from farms or forests so sustainable agriculture is a strategic priority.
claude4: Rationale: The text describes Unilever's sourcing dependency and strategic priority but lacks explicit causal interaction. No actor is shown influencing another across scales - only a correlation between sourcing patterns and strategic focus is implied.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever is a single company making strategy decisions.; Environmental and Societal: Farms and forests as broader land-use/ecosystem sources of raw materials.
gpt5: Summary: [Environmental and Societal | Organizational] Reliance on farms/forests drives Unilever to prioritize sustainable agriculture.
gpt5: Rationale: The text ties resource origins (farms/forests) to Unilever’s strategy, indicating cross-scale causality. No explicit inter-organizational system is mentioned, so only two scales are used.
4o: Rationale: The paragraph describes Unilever's sourcing strategy but does not explicitly state a causal interaction between different scales.

These sources are categorized as Inter-Organizational/Sector, representing the agricultural and forestry supply chains. This establishes a direct causal influence where the Inter-Organizational/Sector scale provides essential inputs to the Organizational scale.

Full Paragraph Text: Smallholder farmers produce 70% of the world’s food and make up 85% of the world’s farmers. Most grow their crops on less than two hectares and are often cut off from training so lack knowledge of how to maximise incomes by improving their agricultural practices. Many of our smallholder farmers are women.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph presents descriptive statistics about smallholder farmers but contains no explicit causal interactions between different scales. It describes characteristics and challenges but lacks any cross-scale influence mechanisms.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Individual: Smallholder farmers are specific people/households.; Environmental and Societal: The global food supply ('the world’s food') is a societal-level system.
gpt5: Summary: [Individual, Environmental and Societal] Smallholder farmers' production directly shapes the global food supply (70%).
gpt5: Rationale: The text explicitly links smallholder farmers to the global food supply via production. No organization or sector actor is named for the training issue, so no cross-scale link is warranted there. Only two clear scales apply.
4o: Rationale: The paragraph describes the situation of smallholder farmers but does not explicitly mention any cross-scale causal interactions between defined scales.
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: N/A
gemini2.5: Summary: N/A
gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph describes conditions and consequences for individual farmers (e.g., lacking knowledge due to being cut off from training) but does not explicitly identify an actor at a different scale causally influencing or being influenced by these farmers. The agent responsible for farmers being 'cut off from training' is not specified, preventing the identification of an explicit cross-scale causal link.

Full Paragraph Text: Through our own supply chain, our suppliers and our NGO partners, we are providing help and training to 800,000 smallholders to enable them to adopt sustainable practices. This helps them to increase yields, increase profits, invest and become more competitive while Unilever benefits from better yields, sustainably produced crops and security of raw material supply. However, assessing the impact of our programmes on farmers’ livelihoods is a complex area and our challenge is to find a practical and cost-effective means to demonstrate this.
claude4: Links: Organizational -> Individual | Individual -> Organizational | Inter-Organizational / Sector -> Individual
claude4: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever as a company and NGO partners as organizations; Individual: 800,000 smallholders as specific people; Inter-Organizational / Sector: Supply chain system involving multiple organizations
claude4: Summary: [Organizational, Individual, Inter-Organizational] Unilever trains smallholders who then provide better yields back to the company
claude4: Rationale: The text shows explicit bidirectional causality between Unilever (organizational) and smallholders (individual), plus supply chain influence on farmers. All interactions are clearly stated with specific outcomes.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Unilever (the company) provides help and benefits from outcomes.; Individual: Smallholders (farmers) receiving training and changing practices.
gpt5: Summary: [Organizational, Individual] Unilever trains smallholders, whose improved yields and sustainable crops secure Unilever’s raw material supply.
gpt5: Rationale: Text explicitly states Unilever aids smallholders and that their improved yields benefit Unilever. Supply chain/NGOs are channels, not explicit cross-scale actors here, so omitted.
4o: Scale Explanations: Individual: Smallholders are specific people receiving training.; Organizational: Unilever is the organization providing help.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The supply chain involves multiple organizations.
4o: Summary: [Individual, Organizational, Inter-Organizational] Supply chain aids smallholders, who in turn benefit Unilever with better yields.
4o: Rationale: The supply chain (Inter-Org) aids smallholders (Individual), who then improve yields benefiting Unilever (Organizational). These are clear cross-scale interactions.
gemini2.5: Links: Organizational -> Individual | Inter-Organizational / Sector -> Individual | Individual -> Organizational
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Individual: Refers to '800,000 smallholders' and 'farmers', specific people.; Organizational: Refers to 'we' (Unilever), 'our suppliers', and 'our NGO partners', which are single organizations.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: Refers to 'our own supply chain', a system among organizations.

Organizational actors (Unilever, suppliers, NGO partners) and the Inter-Organizational supply chain directly influence Individual smallholders by providing training. In turn, the actions of Individual smallholders causally benefit the Organizational actor (Unilever). All identified scales are within the allowed limit of three.

Full Paragraph Text: In February 2014 we signed a five-year partnership with the International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD) to improve the livelihoods of smallholder farmers. Signed by IFAD President Kanayo F Nwanze and our CEO, Paul Polman, the partnership aims to help improve food security, by raising agricultural productivity and linking farmers to markets.

Full Paragraph Text: In January 2014, we signed a partnership with our supplier, Symrise, and overseas development agency GIZ to source vanilla from Madagascar. The programme is set to benefit 4,000 farmers in 32 villages.

Full Paragraph Text: In 2014 we published our Responsible Sourcing Policy (RSP). The RSP embodies our commitment to conduct business with integrity, openness, and respect for universal human rights and core labour principles. The RSP breaks new ground by defining a ‘continuous improvement ladder’ to help our suppliers move from a base level of ‘do no harm’ to ‘good practice’ and ultimately up to ‘best practice’ and as such is intended progressively to replace our Supplier Code in our dealings with key suppliers. The new code has been introduced to the supply base through communications and engagement from Procurement, and also through targeted events in critical markets such as Brazil, China and Vietnam.
claude4: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The company publishing RSP and their Procurement department taking action; Inter-Organizational / Sector: Supply base and suppliers being influenced by the policy implementation
claude4: Summary: [Organizational, Inter-Organizational] Company implements RSP to influence supplier practices through systematic engagement
claude4: Rationale: Clear hierarchical interaction where the organizational actor (company/Procurement) causally influences the inter-organizational system (supply base) through policy implementation and targeted communications. The RSP is designed to move suppliers up the improvement ladder, showing explicit cross-scale influence.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The company and its Procurement team issuing and communicating the RSP.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: The supply base/suppliers collectively as the firm's inter-organizational network.
gpt5: Summary: [Organizational, Inter-Organizational / Sector] The company’s Procurement introduced the RSP to the supply base, shaping suppliers’ practices.
gpt5: Rationale: Explicit wording shows the organization communicating a new code to the supply base, affecting suppliers collectively. Societal norms are mentioned but do not causally act on the firm here, so excluded.
4o: Scale Explanations: Organizational: The company implementing the Responsible Sourcing Policy.; Inter-Organizational: The supply chain and suppliers affected by the policy.
4o: Summary: [Organizational, Inter-Organizational] The company's RSP aims to elevate supplier practices from basic to best through structured guidance.
4o: Rationale: The paragraph describes how the company's policy (Organizational) is designed to influence suppliers (Inter-Organizational) to improve their practices. The focus is on the interaction between these two scales.
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Refers to 'we' (the company), 'Procurement' (a department), and 'our suppliers' (individual companies).; Inter-Organizational / Sector: Refers to the 'supply base', which is a collective system of suppliers.
gemini2.5: Summary: [Organizational, Inter-Organizational / Sector] An organizational unit introduced a new code to its inter-organizational supply base.
gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph describes a company's Procurement department (Organizational) introducing a new policy to its 'supply base' (Inter-Organizational), establishing a clear causal link between these two distinct scales. Other interactions mentioned, such as the company's policy influencing its individual suppliers, occur within the Organizational scale and are therefore not included. Only two distinct scales were identified.

Full Paragraph Text: Unilever is one of the world’s biggest tea suppliers with brands such as Lipton, PG tips and Brooke Bond. We are helping to safeguard the world’s tea supply through an R&D programme to cultivate sustainable varieties.

claude4: Rationale: Clear causal link where Unilever (organizational actor) directly influences global tea supply (societal-level resource) through their R&D activities. Only two distinct scales present with explicit cross-scale causality.

gpt5: Rationale: The text explicitly links Unilever’s organizational action to an effect on the global tea supply system. Brands are mentioned descriptively and do not form additional cross-scale causal links.

Full Paragraph Text: Our partnership with Nature Source Genetics uses plant breeding to meet global demand while supporting communities that rely on the crop for income. The aim is to enhance productivity, quality and overall sustainability, and help stem any decline in crop diversity that could limit its ability to withstand drought, disease and pests.

claude4: Summary: [Organizational, Environmental and Societal] Partnership addresses global demand and community support through plant breeding
claude4: Rationale: The organizational partnership explicitly aims to meet global demand and support communities, showing clear causality from organizational action to societal outcomes. Only two distinct scales are present in the text.

Full Paragraph Text: In his first Independence Day address in 2014, Narendra Modi, India’s new Prime Minister, made a commitment that by 2019 every Indian would have access to a toilet. The promise highlights that about 2.5 billion people globally are without access to adequate sanitation, good hygiene and safe drinking water. There are still 46 countries in the world where less than half the population has access to adequate sanitation facilities. 800,000 children die every year from diarrhoea caused by unsafe water, and poor sanitation and hygiene.
claude4: Rationale: The paragraph presents statistics and a political commitment but lacks explicit causal relationships between different scales. Modi's promise represents governmental intent rather than demonstrated cross-scale influence on outcomes.
gpt5: Scale Explanations: N/A
gpt5: Summary: N/A
gpt5: Rationale: The text states a promise and reports statistics/causes (unsafe water, poor sanitation) without identifying cross-scale actors causing effects. Any implied chains involve non-actors (disease) or same-scale subjects.
4o: Scale Explanations: Individual: Refers to 'every Indian' having access to a toilet.; Environmental and Societal: Refers to global sanitation issues and statistics.
4o: Summary: [Individual, Environmental and Societal] Global sanitation issues influence the commitment to provide toilets to individuals.
4o: Rationale: The paragraph describes a societal issue (global sanitation) that influences a commitment to change conditions for individuals (every Indian). The focus is on the impact of societal-level problems on individual access to sanitation.
gemini2.5: Scale Explanations: Individual: Refers to specific people or groups of people (e.g., 'every Indian', 'people globally', 'children', 'population').; Environmental and Societal: Refers to governmental actors (e.g., 'Narendra Modi, India’s new Prime Minister', 'countries') and societal-level conditions/systems (e.g., 'unsafe water, and poor sanitation and hygiene').
gemini2.5: Summary: [Individual, Environmental and Societal] A Prime Minister's commitment and societal conditions of sanitation and water directly influence the health and access of individuals.
gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph explicitly describes two instances of Environmental and Societal scale actors/conditions influencing individuals. Narendra Modi (Environmental and Societal) made a commitment impacting 'every Indian' (Individual). Furthermore, 'unsafe water, and poor sanitation and hygiene' (Environmental and Societal conditions) are stated to cause death in 'children' (Individual). Only two distinct scales were identified, both showing clear cross-scale causality.

Full Paragraph Text: Transformational change is needed to combat these issues. Unilever is uniquely placed to help because of our expertise in consumer behaviour change, our global reach and our portfolio of health and hygiene brands, including Domestos, Lifebuoy and Pureit, our water purifier. However, bringing about widespread, sustainable behaviour change is not something we can do alone, so we need to work closely with governments, NGOs, academia and funding partners to increase our reach and impact.

claude4: Rationale: Unilever explicitly describes its causal influence on societal issues through consumer behavior change expertise. The company also describes necessary collaboration with multiple organizational partners, creating a second cross-scale interaction.

gpt5: Rationale: The text explicitly ties government collaboration to increased organizational reach, and Unilever to causing consumer behaviour change. We limit to three scales; NGOs/academia/funders are additional orgs omitted to avoid exceeding the cap.

Full Paragraph Text: In 2014 we committed to help 25 million people gain improved access to a toilet by 2020. By helping people who don’t have a toilet to get one and by promoting the benefits of using a clean toilet, we will open new markets and drive demand for our products.

claude4: Rationale: Clear bidirectional interaction where organizational action (helping people get toilets) influences individuals, who then influence organizational outcomes (market demand). Both causal directions are explicitly stated in the text.

These individual actions then create demand, influencing the Organizational actor. Finally, the Organizational actor directly impacts the Environmental and Societal scale by opening new markets. Full Paragraph Text: Lifebuoy has long championed the health benefits of handwashing with soap and aims to change the hygiene behaviour of 1 billion consumers across Asia, Africa and Latin America. To achieve this ambition, we have to find ways to scale up our programmes: we need to develop lower cost, mass-scale behaviour change approaches and expand our partnerships and co-investment models. Lifebuoy has enjoyed four years of sequential double-digit sales growth.
claude4: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Lifebuoy as a specific brand/company with programmes and sales; Individual: 1 billion consumers whose hygiene behavior Lifebuoy aims to change; Inter-Organizational / Sector: Partnerships and co-investment models involving multiple organizations
claude4: Summary: [Organizational, Individual, Inter-Organizational] Lifebuoy targets consumer behavior change through scaled programmes and partnerships
claude4: Rationale: Two clear cross-scale links exist: Lifebuoy (organizational) directly targeting consumer behavior change (individual) and expanding into partnership models (inter-organizational). The text explicitly describes causal intentions rather than mere correlations.

gpt5: Scale Explanations: Organizational: Lifebuoy (a brand) runs programmes and sets strategy.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: Partnerships and co-investment models among organizations.; Individual: Consumers whose hygiene behaviour is targeted.
gpt5: Summary: [Organizational, Inter-Organizational / Sector, Individual] Lifebuoy targets consumer behaviour change and will expand partnerships to help achieve it.
gpt5: Rationale: The text explicitly links Lifebuoy’s actions to consumers and to expanding partnerships to reach them. Three scales suffice; no societal/government actor is specified. Sales growth is stated without causal ties.
4o: Scale Explanations: Individual: Refers to the 1 billion consumers whose hygiene behavior is targeted.; Organizational: Lifebuoy as a company aiming to change consumer behavior.; Inter-Organizational / Sector: Partnerships and co-investment models Lifebuoy seeks to expand.

gemini2.5: Rationale: The paragraph explicitly describes Lifebuoy (Organizational) acting to influence consumers (Individual) and to expand its collaborations (Inter-Organizational / Sector). Two distinct cross-scale causal links are identified. No more than three scales were needed to capture these interactions.

Full Paragraph Text: Women are the majority of our consumer base and their purchasing decisions are pivotal to our growth. They are strongly represented in our agricultural supply chains and in the distribution of our brands to market. At the same time we are a large employer and need the best available talent to succeed in our business goals.

Full Paragraph Text: But women around the world face discrimination and disadvantage, lack access to skills and training, and face obstacles to economic participation.

It presents static descriptions of discrimination, lack of access, and obstacles without specifying who creates these conditions or how they operate across organizational levels.
